name: Key of Solomon
shortDescription: Medieval grimoire (14th-15th century manuscripts) attributed to King Solomon, teaching ceremonial magic including spirit conjuration, circle construction, consecration of magical tools, and creation of pentacles for commanding spirits and gaining knowledge
fullDescription: The Key of Solomon (Latin: Clavicula Salomonis) is one of the most influential grimoires in Western ceremonial magic, a comprehensive manual of ritual magic practices attributed to the legendary wisdom of King Solomon, biblical king renowned for commanding spirits and demons. Surviving in numerous manuscripts from the 14th-15th centuries onward (though claiming much greater antiquity), the text represents a synthesis of Jewish mysticism, Christian demonology, Greco-Roman magic, and medieval ceremonial practice. The grimoire is organized into two books containing detailed instructions for conjuring and commanding spirits, constructing magical circles and triangles, consecrating ritual implements (sword, knife, wand, pentacles, vestments), observing proper planetary timing, performing purifications, and creating pentacles (talismanic seals) for various purposes‚Äîwealth, love, protection, invisibility, knowledge, and spirit control. The Key teaches that the magician, through purity, prayer, and proper ceremonial procedure, becomes a channel of divine authority capable of commanding celestial and infernal spirits. The text emphasizes the magician's moral purity, Christian faith, and ritual precision as essential to success and safety. S.L. MacGregor Mathers' 1889 English translation brought the Key to widespread occult attention, becoming foundational for the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn and modern ceremonial magic. The grimoire's system of pentacles, spirit hierarchies, and ritual procedures influenced virtually all subsequent Western grimoires and remains central to contemporary magical practice.

textStructure.form: Practical ritual manual with instructions and diagrams
textStructure.language: Originally Latin and Hebrew; many vernacular versions (French, Italian, English)

contents: Preliminary instructions on purity and preparation
Construction of magical circle and triangle
Days and hours for operations (planetary timing)
Preparation of virgin parchment, pen, ink
Consecration of magical instruments (sword, knife, sickle, poniard, dagger, lance, wand, staff)
Pentacles of Solomon and their uses
Times and seasons for magical operations
Experiments and their requisites (specific magical operations)
Love magic, treasure finding, invisibility, binding spirits

textStructure.pentacles: 44 pentacles divided among seven planetary categories (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, Moon), each with specific powers and uses
textStructure.diagrams: Elaborate illustrations of circles, triangles, pentacles, Hebrew divine names, spirit seals

historicalContext.attribution: Attributed to King Solomon (c. 970-931 BCE), legendary Israelite king who commanded spirits to build the Temple
historicalContext.actualDate: Earliest extant manuscripts 14th-15th century; possibly based on earlier Greek or Arabic sources now lost
historicalContext.sources: Draws on Jewish angelology (Testament of Solomon), Christian grimoire tradition, Arabic magical texts, Greco-Roman ceremonial magic
historicalContext.manuscripts: Hundreds of manuscript versions across Europe (Italian, French, German, Latin, English) with significant variations
historicalContext.culturalContext: Medieval and Renaissance learned magic; practiced by educated clerics, scholars, and nobles seeking hidden knowledge and power
historicalContext.solomonicLegend: Solomon's wisdom and spirit-commanding ability became template for medieval magic; Testament of Solomon (1st-3rd century CE) established his magical authority
historicalContext.christianization: Grimoire frames magic within Christian cosmology‚Äîinvoking God, Jesus, angels; spirits are demons to be dominated through divine names
historicalContext.influence: Foundation for Lemegeton (Lesser Key of Solomon), Heptameron, Grand Grimoire, and virtually all later European ceremonial magic

keyTeachings: Divine Authority Over Spirits: The magician operates through God's authority, using divine and angelic names to command spirits; success depends on purity, faith, and ritual precision, not personal power
Planetary Timing: All magical operations must be performed during appropriate planetary hours, days, and astrological conditions; each planet governs specific types of magic and spirits
Circle and Triangle: Magical circle protects the magician through divine names and seals; spirits are conjured into the triangle where they can be seen and commanded safely

Consecration of Tools: All magical implements must be created during specific planetary hours, consecrated through elaborate rituals, and never used for mundane purposes; tools channel divine and planetary forces
Purity and Preparation: Magician must undergo ritual purification (bathing, fasting, prayer, sexual abstinence) before operations; moral purity is essential for commanding spirits

Pentacles as Talismans: The 44 pentacles inscribed with divine names, angelic seals, and Hebrew letters serve as tools for specific purposes‚Äîeach must be created at proper time on appropriate materials
Hierarchies of Spirits: Spirits are organized hierarchically (angelic, aerial, terrestrial, infernal) with specific ruling spirits, subordinates, and domains; knowing the hierarchy enables control
Conjuration Formula: Spirits are summoned through graduated conjurations‚Äîbeginning politely, escalating to commands and threats using divine names if the spirit proves reluctant or rebellious
practicalApplications: Spirit Evocation: Summoning angels, planetary spirits, or demons into the triangle for knowledge, favors, teaching, or to compel service; foundational practice of ceremonial magic
Talismanic Magic: Creating and consecrating pentacles for specific purposes‚Äîprotection, wealth, love, invisibility, finding treasure, gaining wisdom, binding enemies
Tool Consecration: Ritual creation and empowerment of magical implements still used in modern Wicca, ceremonial magic, and folk magic traditions
Circle Casting: The Solomonic circle became template for protective sacred space in countless magical traditions including Wicca and modern witchcraft
Golden Dawn System: Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn incorporated Solomonic methods, pentacles, and divine names into their comprehensive magical curriculum
Goetic Magic: The grimoire's spirit conjuration methods were elaborated in the Goetia (Lesser Key of Solomon), still practiced in modern demonology and spirit work
Planetary Magic: System of planetary hours, correspondences, and timing remains standard in Western astrology and magical practice
Theurgic Practice: High ceremonial magic adapted Solomonic methods for invoking angels and achieving mystical union with divine forces
